Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my ears as she explained how important it was for me to lead the upcoming family ceremony. “It’s your turn,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of us—our traditions were the glue that held our family together. But as I nodded, my mind drifted to the notice I’d seen at the construction site that morning. There was an optional training session next week, one that my supervisor hinted could lead to more responsibility and better pay. The team was counting on me to step up, to show I was serious about my work. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my family’s hopes on one side, my coworkers’ trust on the other. My stomach twisted as I tried to imagine how I could possibly be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
